doc.after: As the common name suggests, the fungus is highly toxic, and is responsible for the majority of fatal mushroom poisonings worldwide.[1][43][44] Its biochemistry has been researched intensively for decades,[31] and 30Â grams (1Â oz), or half a cap, of this mushroom is estimated to be enough to kill a human.[45] In 2006, a family of three in Poland was poisoned, resulting in one death and the two survivors requiring liver transplants.[46] Some authorities strongly advise against putting suspected death caps in the same basket with fungi collected for the table and to avoid touching them.[18][47] Furthermore, the toxicity is not reduced by cooking, freezing, or drying.[48]
